channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
java-unrar jar & pom file.

The jar file is from java-unrar homepage : http://sourceforge.net/projects/java-unrar.

should be deployed in the maven repository.
Maven (netbeans) project containing the parser, test code and configuration
But it looks like that jar might be might be LGPLed, no?

It looks like it is LGPL indeed (http://sourceforge.net/projects/java-unrar
).

I'm not familiar with every practical implication of every licensing scheme,
but if I'm correct LGPL means that the library can be used for both open
source and commercial uses. Without the obligation to open source your own
application. Am I right ?
The java-unrar-0.2.zip package comes with a fairly permissive license.txt file. Though it might be a good idea to contact the author for clarification of the licensing terms.

You want me to talk to the guys ? Or is this for the 'legal' Tika department
?
Ideally you'd talk to them and ask them to consider releasing the library under ASL v2. Or maybe there already is something like that out there?

Isn't LGPL already allowing the usage of java-unrar in Tika ? So why should
they change their license ?
No, I believe we cannot have copies of LGPL software in Apache.
This is true, please see http://www.apache.org/licenses/GPL-compatibility.html for details.

The reply from Edmund - developer of the java-unrar library.

Hello,
unfortunately the unrar license applies to most of the junrar code. it
does not allow to rebuild the rar compression algorithm the
decompression is open source and can be/was used (see licence.txt). the
parts that are independent from unrar are lgpl, but its difficult to
separate.

Best,
Edmund

My quick reading of the unrar license suggests that it would be acceptable as an Apache depencency. Instead of the partial LGPL licensing, would the java-unrar author willing to license the entire library under the unrar license?

Jan asked for and got a relicensed version of the java-unrar library. I'm attaching it here for the record.

I filed LEGAL-52 to get official clearance on the license terms.

LEGAL-52 has since been resolved, declaring the UnRAR license as a "Category B" license, so we can use this library as a binary dependency.

Unfortunately it seems like the sourceforge project has gone missing, so I uploaded the latest sources from the above attachment to http://github.com/jukka/java-unrar and added an extra RARParser class that makes this library act as a drop-in plugin for Tika.
The project can now be found here: https://github.com/edmund-wagner/junrar

Would one of our Maven gurus be able to work on getting junrar (as taken from the new github site) into Maven Central?

We could then pull over Jukka's parser to Tika itself

The original junrar still has some dependencies that were removed in Jukka's version. I think these changes should also be applied to the original. I will talk to Edmund about this.

Update: The changes are done now. Edmund want's to release it in a separate maven repository

The changes are done now.

Cool!

Edmund want's to release it in a separate maven repository

Any chance he would consider pushing it directly to Central? Sonatype's hosted OSS repositories [1] are very easy to set up and use, and they'll automatically get synced to Central.

[1] http://nexus.sonatype.org/oss-repository-hosting.html
Has there been any luck getting junrar into Maven Central yet?
Hi any news on this?
Nope, we're still awaiting someone with the appropriate maven-foo to push the jars to Maven Central. Once that's done, we can add the code to Tika to use the library
It looks like junrar-0.7 was mavenized.

Great news!

Since Jukka has previously already written a rar parser based on an older version of the library, it probably makes sense for him to be the one to integrate the parser

In r1577039 I've added test-documents.rar, based on the same documents and structure as the other archive test-documents files, which can hopefully be used in a unit test for the parser
This is based on junrar-0.7, enabling a much simpler version of the parser. To do: include binary dependency and integrate tests from Tika-rar.zip.
Did someone take a look on RARParser.patch?

I'd been hoping Jukka would, sorry, have just done so now

The parser class looks to have some weird indents, any chance you could reformat it to have consistent whitespace? (No tabs, 4 spaces IIRC is the Tika standard)

Secondly, any chance of a JUnit testcase for this new parser? You ought to be able to largely crib off the other archive format unit tests, and use the test rar file I added back in March
Sorry for the long delay. Patch with 4 spaces indents and an unit test using test-documents.rar created by Nick Burch.

SUCCESS: Integrated in tika-trunk-jdk1.7 #428 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/tika-trunk-jdk1.7/428/)
TIKA-241 Unrar parser from Luis Filipe Nassif (nick: http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/tika/trunk/?view=rev&rev=1651619)

  • /tika/trunk/tika-bundle/pom.xml
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/pom.xml
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/src/main/java/org/apache/tika/parser/pkg/RarParser.java
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/src/main/resources/META-INF/services/org.apache.tika.parser.Parser
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/src/test/java/org/apache/tika/parser/pkg/RarParserTest.java

SUCCESS: Integrated in tika-trunk-jdk1.6 #413 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/tika-trunk-jdk1.6/413/)

    TIKA-241 Unrar parser from Luis Filipe Nassif (nick: http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/tika/trunk/?view=rev&rev=1651619)
  • /tika/trunk/tika-bundle/pom.xml
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/pom.xml

Thanks, applied with a few tweaks (mostly for the OSGi bundle) in r1651619.

In r1651625, I then refactored the logic in PackageParser for handling the xhtml+metadata of archive entries, and re-used that from RarParser so the two are consistent

SUCCESS: Integrated in tika-trunk-jdk1.7 #429 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/tika-trunk-jdk1.7/429/)
TIKA-241 Refactor to use common logic between PackageParser and RarParser for populating xhtml+metadata of embedded resources (nick: http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/tika/trunk/?view=rev&rev=1651625)

  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/src/main/java/org/apache/tika/parser/pkg/PackageParser.java
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/src/main/java/org/apache/tika/parser/pkg/RarParser.java
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/src/test/java/org/apache/tika/parser/pkg/AbstractPkgTest.java
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/src/test/java/org/apache/tika/parser/pkg/ArParserTest.java
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/src/test/java/org/apache/tika/parser/pkg/Bzip2ParserTest.java
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/src/test/java/org/apache/tika/parser/pkg/RarParserTest.java
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/src/test/java/org/apache/tika/parser/pkg/TarParserTest.java
  • /tika/trunk/tika-parsers/src/test/java/org/apache/tika/parser/pkg/ZipParserTest.java
Don't we need to add licensing info about unrar license to NOTICE.txt and README.txt? Or this is done only on release?

In r1651709, I've added the unrar license to what I believe are the appropriate places (license not notice files).

Would be good if someone could double-check the rules, especially those on http://www.apache.org/legal/ and the guide at http://incubator.apache.org/guides/releasemanagement.html#best-practice-license, and confirm if I've got it right!

Sorry for the noise i found this bug only today
which introduce junrar as BR/R for Apache Tika. i don't understand the reason
for use non free code if such usage restriction makes the license incompatible with The Open Source Definition and The Free Software Definition. Because Tika library distribution includes this software, it effectively becomes proprietary software itself.

Hi Gil,

Sorry, not sure what you mean by "as BR/R".

Regarding the license issue, from reading the older comments on this issue it seems that (a) junrar was re-released under the "unrar" license (it was LGPL), and (b) Apache legal reviewed the unrar license (see LEGAL-52) and classified it as "Category B", which means it's OK to have junrar as a dependency.
